;联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯周四呼吁立即采取激进行动应对气候变化，他表示破纪录的七月气温表明地球已经从变暖阶段进入“全球沸腾时代”。

;

;秘书长发表上述言论之际，联合国和欧盟监测员表示，七月将成为全球最热的月份。记录了历史，可能是数千年来“前所未有”的，警告说这是世界气候未来的一次尝试。

;

;古特雷斯在纽约发表讲话，将北半球的酷热描述为“残酷的夏天” ”。

;

;“对于整个地球来说，这是一场灾难，”他说，并指出“如果未来几天不出现迷你冰河时代，2023 年 7 月将全面打破记录”。 “气候变化就在这里。这太可怕了。而这仅仅是开始。全球变暖的时代已经结束；全球沸腾的时代已经到来。”

;

;本月，全球变暖加剧的灼热天气已经烘烤了欧洲、亚洲和北美部分地区，再加上烧焦了加拿大和南欧部分地区的野火。< /p>;

;由于 7 月前三周的全球平均气温已高于任何可比时期，世界气象组织和欧洲哥白尼气候变化服务中心 (C3S) 表示，“极有可能”2023 年 7 月将是最热的上个月的记录可以追溯到 20 世纪 40 年代。

;

;C3S 主任 Carlo Buontempo 表示，这一时期的气温“非常惊人”，异常现象如此之大，以至于科学家们相信该记录甚至已经被打破了在月底之前。

;

;除了这些官方记录之外，他说，更早以前的气候代理数据（例如树木年轮或冰芯）表明该时期的气温可能“在我们的历史上是前所未有的” ”。

;

;大火肆虐，希腊消防飞机坠毁，两人死亡

;

;据哥白尼称，上一个最热的月份是 2019 年 7 月，该公司将发布最终结果古特雷斯表示，气候变化的极端影响符合科学家的“预测和反复警告”，并补充说“唯一令人惊讶的是变化的速度”。< /p>;

;面对“悲剧性”后果，他再次呼吁采取迅速而深远的行动，再次瞄准化石燃料行业。

;

;“空气令人难以呼吸。炎热难以忍受。化石燃料利润和气候不作为的水平是不可接受的，”葡萄牙前总理说道。

;

;“领导人必须带头，”他说。 “不用再犹豫了。别再找借口。不再等待其他人先采取行动。”

;

;在他定于 9 月主办的气候雄心峰会之前，古特雷斯呼吁发达国家承诺尽可能在 2040 年实现碳中和，并新兴经济体尽可能在 2050 年之前实现这一目标。

;

;他表示，人类造成的“破坏”“绝不能引发绝望，而应采取行动”，并警告说，为了防止出现最坏的结果，人类“必须转变一年”燃烧的热量变成燃烧雄心的一年”。

;欧盟委员会的预算中没有立即资金，也没有明确的方式来帮助融资消息人士称，随着黑海协议的结束，乌克兰谷物出口将面临额外的运输成本，这给莫斯科带来了获利的机会。

;

;俄罗斯今年退出了联合国主导的黑海谷物协议满载谷物、油籽和小麦的乌克兰货船得以安全通行，抵达全球市场。

;

;俄罗斯已承诺向乌克兰的一些非洲客户提供免费谷物。

;

;乌克兰是世界上最大的粮食出口国之一，现在将不得不几乎完全依赖通过欧盟的昂贵路线，而最便宜的替代动脉多瑙河在爆炸发生后可能无法像希望的那样扩大其出口量。< /p>;

;国际货币基金组织估计全球粮食价格将因此上涨 10-15%。

;

;在路透社看到的一封日期为 7 月 21 日的信中，乌克兰农业部要求欧盟贸易委员会主席瓦尔迪斯·东布罗夫斯基斯 (Valdis Dombrovskis) 向委员会提出财政援助，以支付使用被称为“团结通道”的欧盟替代路线的额外运输成本。乌克兰估计额外成本为每吨 30 美元至 40 美元。

;

;乌克兰粮食交易破裂目前不会对全球粮食供应造成太大影响

;

;本周，欧盟农业专员Janusz Wojciechowski 表示，除非欧盟帮助降低成本，否则俄罗斯可以通过削弱乌克兰而受益。

;

;但是，消息人士称，没有明确的路径。

;

;“我们尚未找到解决方案尚不支持粮食运输。自去年以来，人们一直在摸不着头脑”，一位了解委员会讨论情况的消息人士表示。 “为了简化系统已经付出了很多努力”。

;

;这封信还要求通过“绿色走廊”每月将团结航线扩大 1-150 万吨，包括通往亚得里亚海、波罗的海国家、德国和荷兰。

;

;一位外交消息人士表示，资金非常短缺，只有在中期预算审查之后才能获得大量资金，即使在秋季，中期预算审查也可能需要几个月的时间才能敲定。玉米收获即将到来。

;

;委员会发言人证实收到了这封信，并表示“我们目前正在评估此类请求，并将在适当的时候回复”。

;

;其中一个问题是暂时禁止五个邻国欧盟国家进口乌克兰谷物。这五个国家正在推动延期至 9 月 15 日之后。波兰强烈反对允许乌克兰谷物进入其市场，并表示正在寻求灵活的禁令安排。

;

;这些国家已从欧盟委员会获得了一些补偿资金他们的农民因去年额外粮食的突然涌入而受到沉重打击。

;

;然而，第二位外交消息人士称，阻力正在增加，因为一些州认为支付额外粮食的价值由于这项禁令，运输成本增加。

;

;俄罗斯对乌克兰敖德萨的袭击造成至少 1 人死亡，“摧毁”了联合国教科文组织大教堂

;

;欧盟于去年 5 月暂停关税并设立了团结通道委员会与其他贷款机构拨款 10 亿欧元（11 亿美元），目前仍在支付中，以缓解后勤瓶颈并降低一些成本。

;

;至于运输方面的直接补偿，委员会不确定如何提供帮助。

;

;“我们没有工具，你把钱给谁？还有一个问题竞争……提供（运输）保险不是委员会的职责。各国可以提供保证，但还没有结论性的讨论。”了解委员会讨论情况的消息人士补充道，他指的是由于战争风险而产生的额外成本。

;

;去年，乌克兰将 60% 的关税提高了由于该协议，其 10% 的出口通过团结通道，40% 通过黑海。

;

;在通过邻国欧盟国家运输的货物中，约三分之二沿多瑙河三角洲运输，主要通过罗马尼亚，也是效率最高、成本最低的走廊。

;

;周一，俄罗斯轰炸了多瑙河上的一些乌克兰港口和筒仓。这削弱了欧盟希望在今年年底前将通过团结通道的运输量从每月约 300 万吨增加到每月 5-550 万吨的希望，其中多瑙河运输量高达 400 万吨。

;

;“我们仍在评估风险和损害，”同一消息人士称。

;

;立陶宛提出的另一个选择是波罗的海走廊，但它涉及两次铁路轨距变化，从而增加更多

;

;2022 年 5 月至今年 6 月期间，乌克兰出口农产品总计约 4550 万吨，其中 4100 万吨是谷物，经过欧盟和摩尔多瓦。

; Fri, 28 Jul 2023 00:50:02 +0800 Far-right’s rise in Europe a warning signal for an EU beset with challengeshttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3228950/far-rights-rise-europe-warning-signal-eu-beset-challenges?utm_source=rss_feed

;极右翼正在 2023 年席卷欧洲。最近的选举结果已经可见许多极右翼政党增加了欧洲各地的选票和席位份额。在西欧，意大利、奥地利、法国、德国、荷兰、希腊等国极右翼政党的支持率均有所上升。

;

;在匈牙利、波兰等东欧国家，极右翼政党的支持率均有所上升。 -右翼政党控制着政府。北欧也出现了极右翼政党的崛起，最近在瑞典和芬兰等国家出现。

;

;最重要的是，意大利 2022 年 9 月提前举行的大选预示着该国政治的新时代，新总理乔治亚·梅洛尼领导的极右翼联合政府，由她的极右翼政党“意大利兄弟”和马泰奥·萨尔维尼的极右翼联盟党组成，并得到了保守的中右翼政党“意大利力量”的支持。;

;在意大利，更令人惊讶的是，自 1945 年二战结束以来，该国已经经历了 68 届政府。平均大约每 1.1 年就有一次。

;

;欧洲政治领域的极右翼政党历来倾向于关注三个核心问题。首先，本土主义，重点是保护自己的族群内群体免受移民等外族群体的侵害。

;

;其次，这些政党往往采取独裁政策，例如严厉打击犯罪和促进法律和秩序问题。第三，欧洲极右翼政党经常提倡民粹主义信息传递技巧，例如声称代表普通民众反对他们认为的社会腐败政治精英。

;

;那么，新的内容是什么？现代极右翼在欧洲的崛起？过去，极右翼政党被视为只会搞一招的小马，主要关注单一问题领域，例如反移民政策或反对欧盟 (EU)。

;

;这已不再是这种情况。我们在欧洲看到的是极右翼政党策略的多元化。整个非洲大陆的极右政党不再只是反移民或反欧盟。

;

;许多政党已经改变了选举策略，寻求为选民提供更广泛的平台。新的战略包括关注生态民族主义等问题，着眼于限制移民或在欧盟之外重建国家主权。

;

;气候变化如何帮助推动德国极右翼的崛起< /h3>;

;欧洲几个极右翼政党的第二个策略是不再提倡“硬”脱欧，例如法国的马琳·勒庞领导的全国集会党和意大利萨尔维尼的联盟党。欧盟，在政治学中被称为“硬欧洲怀疑论”。相反，他们寻求从内部改革欧盟，通过缩小欧盟规模，倡导一种更温和的欧洲怀疑主义形式。

;

;欧洲政治光谱左翼和右翼的主流政党如何应对应对极右翼的挑战？我最近与人合着的研究表明，在 2015-18 年欧洲难民危机期间，欧洲各地的主流中右翼政党（保守党和基督教民主党）如何看到极右翼在移民问题上构成的威胁，并采取更严厉的反制措施。短期内，这种选举策略对这些中右翼政党来说是成功的，因为一些政党设法继续执政，并在选举中击败了极右翼政党。全国议会选举。然而，从长远来看，这种策略是危险的，因为它可能会导致主流政党重塑其意识形态，变得像他们旨在击败的极右翼政党一样。

;

;我们的分析还发现了主流化效应这对整个欧洲自由民主的未来具有重要影响。在匈牙利，以前传统的中右翼保守派青民盟现在已经成为一个完全成熟的极右翼政党，推行恶毒的反移民政策。

;

;在总理维克托·欧尔班的领导下，匈牙利经历了民主倒退，该国正在陷入困境。现在被广泛认为是非民主的。随着法律与正义党的崛起，我们在波兰也看到了同样的意识形态转变。这一切对于欧洲政治的未来来说都不是一个好兆头，特别是考虑到一些中欧和东欧政党转向极右翼。

;

;欧洲政治格局的右转反映了政治基础的变化。面临挑战的欧盟的支持和行动。经济危机、英国脱欧、逃离战争和环境破坏的移民、东欧民主倒退以及气候变化都直接挑战着主流中左翼和中右翼政党的治理。

;

;政治和经济从长远来看，Covid-19大流行的余震对欧洲自由民主国家来说是最近且可能最具破坏性的危机。 2024 年 6 月的欧洲议会选举日益临近，这些选举可能会给整个欧洲大陆的极右翼带来进一步的政治冲击和收益。

;香港人无需签证即可在马来西亚逗留三个月，是之前限制的三倍，该国总理在东南亚之行的最后一站会见市领导人李家超后宣布了这一消息。

;

;总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣周四还表示，李家超已通知他香港可以开放贸易两国领导人还讨论了在贸易、投资、技术、教育、安瓦尔在其脸书页面上表示，香港护照持有人现在有权在马来西亚免签证逗留长达90天，比之前的30天增加，该政策从6月28日起生效。

;

;“这将有助于促进商业和旅游活动以及人员往来， ”他说。

;

;根据香港政府发表的声明，李先生感谢马来西亚政府放宽签证要求，这将为护照持有者提供“更大的入境便利”。入境处也确认了新安排。

;

;香港中华总商会主席蔡冠深对延长期限表示欢迎，称“我们可以有时间做生意” ”。

;

;身兼新华集团主席并前往吉隆坡与李显龙会面的崔表示，安瓦尔的领导结束了政治不确定性，并有助于提振投资者信心。

;

; >;

;李约翰宣扬东盟关系，香港与印度尼西亚签署 15 项协议

;

;同日，安瓦尔还宣布了一项新的增长政策框架，旨在将马来西亚打造成世界前 30 强之一十年内实现经济增长。

;

;“这是为了提升我们国家的地位和尊严，有两个主要重点：重组经济，使马来西亚成为亚洲领先的经济体，并最终为人民提供享受更好生活质量的福利。”当地媒体援引他的话说。

;

;据总理称，李说，他的政府正在考虑在吉隆坡设立贸易办事处，以加强两地之间的合作。香港商务及经济发展局在海外主要城市设有14个此类办事处，另有4个在中国内地。

;

;马来西亚目前由香港驻雅加达贸易办事处管辖，该办事处于2016年成立。该市在新加坡和曼谷设有前哨基地，后者于 2019 年设立。

;

;香港和印度尼西亚领导人在雅加达会谈期间重点关注深化经济联系

;

;Danny Lau Tat-香港中小企业协会名誉主席庞对香港在另一个东盟成员国设立另一个贸易办事处的前景表示欢迎。

;

;他补充说，近年来许多公司已探索投资作为所谓“中国加一”战略的一部分，投资者将目光投向大陆以外的地区，以实现业务多元化。

;

;“如果政府能够在该地区设立更多代表处帮助提供当地信息或帮助解决繁文缛节，这将很有用。

;

;李正率领一个由五位高级官员和 30 位来自金融、投资、商业、

;

;香港特首周四还出席了北京驻马来西亚特使欧阳玉晶举办的午餐会，并出席了与全国商会成员举行的晚宴活动

;

;市长告诉当地商界领袖，加强两国之间的贸易和投资合作存在巨大潜力。该活动不对媒体开放。

;

;据中国外交部称，香港和马来西亚公司预计将在周五李将出席的商业论坛上签署多项双边协议。行政长官还计划访问本地公司。

;

;根据香港政府数据，2022年两地贸易额达2200亿港元（281亿美元）。两国互为第九大贸易额贸易伙伴。

;

;香港贸易发展局助理首席经济学家薛冠南表示，鉴于马来西亚公民相对富裕，专注于消费品的公司可能会在马来西亚找到增长机会，数字服务和先进制造企业也是如此。

;

;香港和新加坡在李约翰访问期间签署了 7 项双边协议

;

;新加坡也是香港移民寻求更大住房和生活的热门目的地。粤语的使用相当广泛。

;

;马来西亚是李光耀周日开始的三国之行的最后一站。在与总理李显龙会面并达成七项涉及研究和金融科技合作的非约束性协议后，他于周二离开新加坡。

;

;China and Indonesia should advance their strategic partnership, offering each other opportunities for development, Chinese President Xi Jinping told his Indonesian counterpart Joko Widodo on Thursday.

;

;Welcoming Widodo to the southwestern Chinese city of Chengdu in Sichuan province, Xi said the two countries were “like-minded” and “good partners”.

;

;The two leaders are in Chengdu to attend the opening ceremony of the Fisu World University Games on Friday.

;

;“On the road to state modernisation and national rejuvenation, our two countries share highly convergent concepts and serve as each other's development opportunities,” Xi was quoted by the state broadcaster CCTV as saying.

;

;Widodo's visit comes in the countdown to the launch of the Jakarta-Bandung high-speed railway, which is expected to be up and running next month, seven years after work started.

;

;The line connects Indonesia's two biggest cities and was built by Chinese state-owned enterprises.

;

;Xi said the line was a “significant achievement connecting the Belt and Road Initiative with Indonesia's Global Maritime Fulcrum vision”.

;

;The Chinese president told Widodo that China would support more Indonesian projects such as construction of the country's new capital and the development of the Kalimantan Industrial Park.

;

;Cooperation was also possible in areas such as electric vehicles, smart cities and the digital transformation of industries, Xi said.

;

;In addition, the two countries will launch a dialogue mechanism between foreign ministers and defence ministers.

;

;China is Indonesia's top trading partner, with Indonesia being a key supplier of nickel and other raw materials.

;

;Indonesia also plays an increasingly important role in the rising geopolitical competition between China and the United States in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Xi said China supported Indonesia's Asean chairmanship this year, saying Jakarta promoted “strategic autonomy and solidarity” for the regional bloc.

;

;Widodo said his country was willing to strengthen cooperation with China in areas such as investment, fisheries, food security and medical and health care, according to a report by state news agency Xinhua.

;

;Xi also referred to Widodo as an “old friend” and praised the visits they paid to each other last year.

;

;In July 2022, Widodo became the first leader from another country to visit China outside the Winter Olympics. At the time, Beijing's strict zero-Covid policy was still in place and had greatly reduced international contacts.

;

;In November, Xi travelled to Bali for the Group of 20 summit hosted by Indonesia.

;

;The two leaders on Thursday also signed a series of cooperation deals relating to agricultural products, medicine, joint research and development and several construction projects.

;Despite Israel's political turmoil, China can help bring it back to the negotiating table to help push for peace in the Middle East, according to the top Palestinian envoy to Beijing.

;

;He also urged Beijing and Washington to work together, rather than competing for influence in the region.

;

;In an exclusive interview with the South China Morning Post, Palestinian ambassador Fariz Mehdawi said achieving peace in the Middle East had never been easy since most of the issues were “interlinked with each other”.

;

;He said generating momentum among stakeholders – such as the European Union, and the Brics emerging economy countries – required coordination with Israel to bring it to the table.

;

;China's Xi meets Mahmoud Abbas, offers 3-point plan to resolve Palestinian issue

;

;“This is why we expect China to bring about more partners in its efforts, so that when you push Israel to the corner, with all these peaceful initiatives, they should respond anyway,” Mehdawi said.

;

;During his meeting with Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas in Beijing earlier last month, Chinese President Xi Jinping restated China's willingness to “play a positive role” to solve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, one of the world's most enduring conflicts.

;

;Weeks later, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu confirmed that he had received an invitation for an official visit to China. While it remained unclear if or when the trip would take place, it has raised speculation that Beijing may step in to resolve the conflict.

;

;The peace process between Israelis and the Palestinians has been stalled since 2014, and hopes for a resumption of talks have dimmed as violence in the West Bank has escalated over the past year. The negotiations, which envision the formal establishment of a Palestinian state, have become increasingly uncertain as doubts grow about the credibility of the political leadership of 87-year-old Palestinian Authority president Abbas.

;

;Meanwhile, Israel, which has been pushing to expand Jewish settlements in occupied land, remains mired in political crisis as its hardline nationalist government seek to curb the power of the Supreme Court to overrule government actions, triggering months of mass protests from those opposed to the judicial reform.

;

;Mehdawi acknowledged that the situation for any mediation effort at the moment was difficult.

;

;“Making peace is like dancing, and you need two dancers, but unfortunately, the situation in Israel is not conducive,” Mehdawi said at the embassy in Beijing.

;

;“We can safely say as Palestinians now don't have a partner right now with whom we are going to make peace,” he said, adding that the political division within Israel had made peace negotiations more challenging.

;

;“It's not a favourable situation at this moment, and I think this is where the dilemma [for] China comes.”

;

;Meanwhile, a major geopolitical realignment is taking place in the Middle East, with Beijing's role as a power broker boosted after it helped to restore diplomatic ties between rivals Saudi Arabia and Iran, easing years of animosity between the Sunnis and Shia Muslim-dominated countries.

;

;The detente between Saudi Arabia and Iran marked a watershed moment for diplomacy in the Middle East, a region that has suffered proxy conflicts, paving the way for rapprochement between Iran and other Gulf states, including Qatar, Oman, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.

;

;Mehdawi said Beijing's diplomatic role in the rapprochement was “a remarkable achievement” in helping to stabilise the Middle East.

;

;Since America's abrupt withdrawal from Afghanistan after two decades, as well as the official end of its combat mission in Iraq, observers have speculated about Washington's ebbing influence in the region. Beijing, meanwhile, has been increasingly portrayed as a reliable alternative that has offered trade and investment with no strings attached.

;

;While peace and stability have been high on Beijing's agenda in the Middle East, Mehdawi said there was room for Beijing and Washington to cooperate on issues in the region.

;

;“When [they deal] with the Middle East, both countries have potential and leverage there, and we are in the region also having open minds towards both,” he said. “We would love to see how the US will be able to welcome those Chinese initiatives and work with them in a positive manner, instead of seeing it as an attempt to compete with them. There is no need for competition.”

;

;In June, Chinese and Palestinian leaders announced that the two sides had elevated diplomatic relations to a strategic partnership, with pledges of deeper cooperation ranging from political and economic to tourism and technology.

;

;Under a memorandum of understanding signed in February, Mandarin will be taught in various Palestinian universities.

;

;Further cooperation with China will have to overcome formidable challenges, since the Palestinian territories are still under occupation, but Mehdawi noted the political will on both sides was strong.

;

;Meanwhile, the two sides were ready to conclude negotiations over a Chinese-Palestinian free-trade agreement “soon”.

;

;“Palestine doesn't have a huge market, and I think the Chinese side is quite generous to meet us on very good and very friendly terms. That would help to see that Palestinian products would find their way into the Chinese market.”

;

;The 71-year-old ambassador dismissed the possibility of normalising ties between Israel and the Arab world without peace between the Israelis and Palestinians.

;

;As part of efforts to cement its influence in the Middle East, Washington has been seeking to expand the so-called Abraham Accords, brokered in 2020 under the previous Trump administration, to normalise ties between Israel – a key US ally in the region – and several Arab states, including the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Morocco.

;

;Sudan agreed to join the normalisation deals in 2021, and last month, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the Biden administration was “very much involved” in pushing for a formal relationship between Israel and Saudi Arabia. However, Saudi Arabia has insisted it will only sign an agreement with Israel if a Palestinian state is established.

;

;Mehdawi said that the long-standing conflicts between the Israelis and Palestinians had been the root of “many troubles” in the Middle East, adding that the Palestinian issue could never be sidelined.

;

;Fighting between Israel and the Palestinians just escalated. Is this an uprising?

;

;“Normalising Israel in our region necessitates solving the Palestinian cause as a prerequisite step, not the other way around. Israel needs to live in peace with its neighbour Palestine first. The rest in the region will join as had been already proposed in the Arab Peace Initiative of 2002,” Mehdawi said, referring to the peace plan endorsed by the Arab League in Beirut in 2002.

;

;“No one should think about stabilising the Middle East by passing over Palestine. That would not happen. That's not realistic. That's not even practical. It would not happen, all attempts to marginalise our Palestinian cause had failed and will fail in the future.”

;

;Mehdawi said US Middle East policy under the Trump administration was “disastrous”, marked by a controversial move to shift the US embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem in 2018.

;

;The Biden administration has sought to mend ties with Palestinians. Last year, US President Joe Biden visited the West Bank, where he met Abbas and, like successive US administrations, expressed support for a two-state solution and the establishment of a Palestinian state.

;

;But Mehdawi said the US should do more. For example, Washington should use its leverage to stop Israel's illegal settlement expansion in occupied lands, he said.

;China has called for peace, opposition to hegemony and “bridging differences through dialogue”, as it joins North Korea in marking the 70th anniversary of the Korean war ceasefire.

;

;Chinese state media released a series of articles commemorating the 1950-53 war as a high-level delegation from Beijing arrived in Pyongyang on Wednesday to take part in related events, in the first post-pandemic trip to North Korea by Chinese officials.

;

;The delegation is being led by Li Hongzhong, member of the Politburo and vice-chairman of the standing committee of China's top legislature, the National People's Congress, both centres of power for the ruling Communist Party.

;

;A Russian delegation led by Defence Minister Sergey Shoigu arrived in Pyongyang earlier to join in the celebrations, as North Korea looks to strengthen ties with both key partners amid heightened military activity in the region by the United States and its allies.

;

;In 2018, Xi sent his right-hand man Li Zhanshu, then NPC standing committee chairman and the third-ranking official in the Politburo Standing Committee, the party's top decision-making body, to attend North Korea's 70th anniversary celebrations.

;

;The choice of the lower-ranked Li Hongzhong implied Xi might want to downplay what Beijing has called a “blood-cemented militant friendship”.

;

;Ni Lexiong, a professor at the Shanghai University of Political Science and Law, said: “Compared with [Russian President] Putin's decision to send Defence Minister Shoigu, the attendance of Li Hongzhong reflects the delicate relationship between China and the US, as Beijing doesn't want to irritate Washington and both sides are trying to improve ties.”

;

;Pyongyang staged a military rally on Thursday to mark what it calls “Victory Day”, when the armistice was signed in 1953. Both China and the former Soviet Union supported North Korea in the war against the US, South Korean other armies under the UN banner, and at least 180,000 Chinese troops were killed in action.

;

;In an editorial on Wednesday, Chinese state news agency Xinhua described the armistice as a victory for peace and the people against an invasion by the “US imperialists”. It said China always advocates for peace and stability in a world where “a cold-war mentality and power politics persist”.

;

;“The world is once again standing at the crossroads of history … The world is not peaceful, peace needs to be defended, and justice needs to be defended,” the article said.

;

;“The Communist Party of China leads the Chinese people to always commit to safeguarding international fairness and justice, and promoting world peace and stability … We advocate bridging differences through dialogue, resolving disputes through cooperation, and resolutely oppose all forms of hegemonism and power politics.”

;

;North Korean leader Kim Jong-un on Thursday echoed China's message against hegemony and imperialism, telling Li he would never forget “the brave soldiers” of China who “shed blood to bring about the victory” 70 years ago, North Korea's official agency KCNA reported.

;

;It said Kim visited a cemetery in Pyongyang on Wednesday to pay his respects to the Chinese soldiers killed in the Korean war, including the eldest son of then Chinese president Mao Zedong.

;

;Kim also held a separate meeting with Shoigu on Wednesday, and the pair inspected North Korea's latest weapons – including Hwasong missiles and spy drones resembling the US RQ-4 Global Hawk unmanned aerial vehicles.

;

;Mega hit Chinese film The Battle at Lake Changjin set for a sequel

;

;The White House also released a statement commemorating the war veterans and the US-South Korea alliance.

;

;Li's visit comes as the US-led West ramps up pressure on China to help curb North Korea's military ambitions.

;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned last week that Washington would seek closer defence alliances with Japan and South Korea if China did not use its “unique influence” to help denuclearise the Korean peninsula.

;

;In a letter on Friday, the Group of Seven, European Union and several other countries collectively urged China to help stop North Korea's evasion of UN sanctions through Chinese territorial waters.

;

;In response, the Chinese mission to the United Nations said on Monday Beijing “strictly” implements UN Security Council resolutions.

;

;North Korea's trade with the world has been largely cut off due to UN sanctions since 2006 over its nuclear and ballistic missile programmes, leaving China and Russia as its essential political and trade partners. Both also oppose any further sanctions on Pyongyang.

;

;On Thursday, Li told Kim that China was willing to “promote the healthy and stable development of [bilateral] relations, bring happiness to the people of both countries, and make active contributions to regional peace, stability, prosperity and development,” according to South Korea's Yonhap news agency.

;

;Li also handed over a letter from Xi, according to KCNA. Its contents were not revealed.

;

;Xi and Kim have a long tradition of exchanging personal letters. Xi last sent a letter to Kim in November, in response to a congratulatory message from the Korean leader for having secured a historic third term.

;

;KCNA quoted Xi as pledging to work with Kim on regional stability in the letter, which came shortly after Pyongyang launched a flurry of missile tests in response to US-South Korea war games around the Korean peninsula.

;Increasingly frequent encounters between the Chinese and US warships and military aircraft are difficult to analyse because some of them are not reported, a US military analyst said on Wednesday.

;

;“Part of the challenge of talking about [US-China military incidents] is that a lot of encounters go unreported,” Josiah Case, a research analyst at the Centre for Naval Analyses, said at an event held on Wednesday by the Brookings Institute, a Washington think tank.

;

;“That's why it's hard to say that there is a clear trend line other than what we've been told by [Pentagon] officials in public.

;

;“One thing to keep in mind is the incidents that we've seen over the past few months at sea, and in the air, these are not the first times that the [People's Liberation Army has] behaved unprofessionally.

;

;“I think part of why what we're seeing today is so worrying is that these are happening in a vacuum.”

;

;Encounters between patrolling Chinese and American vessels and aircraft have become increasingly dangerous, US officials have said, because of a lack of high-level communication between the two militaries. Beijing cut several communication channels after former US House speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan last August.

;

;In early June, a Chinese warship came within 137 metres (150 yards) of a US destroyer in the Taiwan Strait and forced it to slow down, which followed claims by the Pentagon in May that a Chinese fighter jet conducted an “unnecessarily aggressive manoeuvre” during an intercept of a US spy plane in international airspace over the South China Sea.

;

;Beijing has pushed back against the allegations by characterising US military operations in the South China Sea area as provocations.

;

;Mao Ning, spokeswoman for China's foreign ministry, said after the fighter jet incident that “such provocative and dangerous actions are the root cause of maritime security issues”.

;

;More recently, Admiral John Aquilino, the head of Indo-Pacific Command, told the Aspen Security Forum in Colorado that attempts to contact his People's Liberation Army counterparts had been disregarded or declined, including an invitation to attend the annual chiefs of defence conference in Fiji next month.

;

;These developments meant Beijing was unlikely to restore formal communications with the US military, Roderick Lee, director of research at China Aerospace Studies Institute, a unit of the US Air Force's Air University, said during the discussion at Brookings.

;

;Lee suggested that Beijing had drawn its own conclusions about US intentions based on the regular air and sea patrols through the region, and therefore saw little value in direct talks.

;

;“What you're saying on the phone is probably the least weighted in terms of value … so I don't think they had any intent to improve formal communication, because I think they think it's already really good,” he said.

;

;“They probably think we're really good at communicating through these non-verbal cues.

;

;“Whether we are or not is another issue. I think that's where the danger is.”

;

;The frequent encounters were likely to continue given PLA's military ambitions and the US' reluctance to pull back their activities in the Pacific region, observers said.

;

;“If we were to pull back our operations … or close-in reconnaissance, if we were to pull these back in an attempt to send goodwill, I do think Beijing would see that as a weakness,” Case said.

;

;However, while both analysts underscored the risks caused by the lack of military-to-military talks amid increasing operations near mainland China, they also noted a higher level of professionalism exhibited by PLA pilots.

;

;Lee used the 2001 collision of a US EP-3 spy plane and a Chinese fighter jet near Hainan Island as a comparison. The pilot of the PLA J-8 jet died in the incident.

;

;According to Lee, the PLA “has pilots that are more proficient, and that will result in them now being directed in a mature way to try to get the US to stop or at least show displeasure to US reconnaissance operations”.

;

;Case agreed.

;

;“The PLA is becoming a more professional military and so but that does not mean that operator error isn't entirely gone,” he said.
